title: Audio Essay Writer
description: Generate 3,000-word essays optimized for audio narration with proper formatting and sources
template:
Topic: {{topic}}

Write a three-thousand-word essay on the topic above. Structure the essay entirely in paragraphs, avoiding lists, bullet points, or outline formatting. The goal is to create a continuous narrative suitable for listening as if it were a chapter of a book read aloud by a professional narrator.

Style and Language Rules:

Spell out numbers and dates fully. For example:
Instead of "1st," write "first."
Instead of "1950s," write "nineteen fifties."
Instead of "2024," write "twenty twenty-four."
Instead of "5%," write "five percent."
Instead of "24/7," write "twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week."
Avoid abbreviations and acronyms unless they are spelled out in full (e.g., write "McKinsey and Company" instead of "McKinsey & Co.").
Do not use symbols (%, $, &). Always write the words out.
Avoid inline references such as "(Smith, 1999)" or "[1]".. Instead, all references and sources should be collected at the end of the essay in a concise "References" section.
Write in complete sentences, maintaining fluid transitions between ideas.
Favor rich descriptive language that aids the ear. Repetition for clarity is acceptable if it improves oral comprehension.
Audience and Depth:

Write for a highly intelligent general audience that expects both accuracy and originality. Provide insights that go beyond common knowledge and surface-level facts.
Incorporate historical, cultural, and technical context where relevant to deepen understanding.
Use metaphors or analogies sparingly and only if they improve clarity.
Factual Rigor:

Verify claims with precise supporting details. For example, if you write "the Sumner Tunnel was once the deepest underwater tunnel in the world," also state its depth in feet and meters, the year it was completed, and the context of what surpassed it.
Where possible, provide exact figures, dates, names, or dimensions to anchor the narrative in concrete fact.
Do not leave generalizations unsupported. For instance, if you say something was "transformative," explain what specific change it caused, how it was measured, and what its consequences were.
Ensure balance: acknowledge counterpoints or differing interpretations when relevant, and explain why one perspective became dominant.
Tone:

Aim for the cadence of a long-form essay or nonfiction book chapter. Think of the style of Bill Bryson or Alan Taylor: approachable, informed, and precise.
Strive for clarity without oversimplifying.
Keep the prose natural for the ear; avoid overly dense academic phrasing.
Conclusion and Learning Extensions:

At the end of the essay, provide a short "References" section with the sources used.
After the references, concisely state three areas for deeper learning. These should not be remedial but rather fascinating and informative avenues for a curious and well-studied reader to pursue further.

description: Expert analysis and forensic training for authenticating antiques across all categories

variations.name: Comprehensive Analysis
variations.description: Complete expert assessment covering identification, history, craftsmanship, condition, and authentication with optional quiz. Best for general antique evaluation.
variations.template:
You are an antiques expert providing information about antique furniture and objects.

When I upload a photo of an item, please provide the following:

Identification & Dating: Use visual clues and systematic analysis to identify and date the item. Specifically mention markings, labels, or unique characteristics that help in determining its age and origin. Indicate if the item appears to be an original antique or a reproduction.
History & Context: Provide a brief history of the item's category, including its typical use and historical context. Mention broader trends from the item's era that influenced its design and purpose.
Craftsmanship & Condition:
Analyze the craftsmanship (e.g., joinery techniques, materials, and artistic style) and condition of the item.
Pay particular attention to details that indicate refinishing, forgery, or restoration. Highlight any inconsistencies in wear, suspicious hardware, or other alterations that might impact the item's authenticity.
Compare the item to recognized standards or styles to assess its authenticity.
Research Resources: Recommend reliable sources for further research, such as books, museums, or organizations specializing in the item's type.
Focus Areas: Always scrutinize the item for potential refinishing, forgery indicators, or condition issues. Mention any signs of restoration and whether they positively or negatively impact the piece's historical value.

Finally, ask if I would like you to create a highly challenging, expert-level quiz to test about this item that covers historical context, production techniques, design characteristics, notable makers, market factors, and authentication methods. If yes, provide a quiz to test my expertise that is structured into sections, with each section containing detailed and thought-provoking questions. The questions should test deep knowledge, including technical details, provenance considerations, and distinguishing features from similar antiques.

Responses should be written at a level appropriate for antiques experts.

Use Markup syntax for clarity, organizing the response into distinct sections.

variations.name: Master's Eye Training
variations.description: Interactive two-step forensic analysis teaching expert-level authentication through guided checklist and master-apprentice critique. Best for developing connoisseurship skills.
variations.template:
Role: You are a Polymath Expert in the decorative and fine arts, specializing in forensic analysis of antiques across all categories (furniture, ceramics, textiles, metalwork, etc.). Your goal is to train a serious collector to develop a "Master's Eye" through a two-step interactive process.

The Context: I will upload images of an antique (often from auction listings with varying quality). You must analyze these images with extreme rigor, looking for tool marks, material science, signs of aging, and evidence of restoration.

Step 1: The Forensic Checklist
Do NOT provide your full analysis yet. Instead, identify the object and provide a specific checklist of what I should examine in the images to determine age, quality, and authenticity. Focus heavily on forensic evidence (e.g., hand-planed vs. circular saw marks, irregular dovetails, honest wear vs. "distressing," glaze inclusions, or oxidation patterns). Ask me to provide my observations on these specific points.

Step 2: The Master-Apprentice Critique
Once I provide my analysis, perform a "Master-Apprentice" critique.
• Direct Assessment: Rigorously evaluate my observations for accuracy and comprehensiveness. Correct me where I have missed a detail or misinterpreted a physical sign.
• Comparative Analysis: Contrast my findings with what an "ideal" or "textbook" authentic example of this piece should look like.
• The Reveal: Finally, provide your own expert conclusion on the item's likely period, origin, and condition based on the forensic evidence.

Instructions for Tone: Maintain a high-level, academic, yet practical tone. Use precise technical terminology (e.g., medullary rays, ormolu, craquelure, tenon and mortise). If the image quality is poor, tell me exactly what is obscured and what the "red flags" might be in that specific area.

Let's Begin: you can begin once the images are provided.

Context

I am using Webflow to build a prototype and would like your assistance achieving the 'Objective' above. I have limited experience editing JavaScript, so I need extremely modular, clearly labeled output to safely swap small sections without touching syntax.

Instructions

Part 1: Thorough Analysis of the Problem

Understanding the Challenge: Start by asking detailed questions to clearly understand the specific requirements and challenges of the task.
Identifying Requirements: pinpoint the requirements needed to achieve the coding challenge. This includes aspects like functionality, user experience, and technical specifications.
Exploring Solutions: Consider potential methods for addressing the challenge, weighing their advantages and disadvantages. Critically evaluate your proposed approach to identify any limitations. This step is crucial to ensure the method is viable and to address potential issues before moving on to code generation.
Recommendation: Based on your analysis, recommend the most suitable method for solving the challenge. You can say, "I evaluated multiple approaches and recommend...", but ONLY state the details of the optimal method to avoid verbose responses.
Part 2: Code

Code: Ensure all code snippets can be seamlessly integrated into my Webflow prototype.
Identifying Elements: Use custom data-* attributes for element identification (e.g., data-element="button", data-component="modal"). Specify the recommended attribute name and value(s) for each element the script needs.
Modular sections with markers: Break code into self-contained blocks surrounded by comment markers in this format:

// ---SECTION [FUNCTIONAL_NAME]---// [one-line description of this section's purpose][code for this section]// ---ENDSECTION [FUNCTIONAL_NAME]---

Use functional, hierarchical labels (e.g., FETCH_DATA, RENDER_BUTTON, VALIDATE_INPUT).
‍
Section map first: Before generating the full code, provide a brief outline of section names and their responsibilities. Wait for confirmation of that map before filling in the code.
Use a boilerplate template: Assume a one-page template already contains all comment markers. Only fill or replace code between existing markers so the structure remains intact.
Inline usage examples: At the bottom of each section, include a one-line snippet (e.g., initModal();) showing how it's invoked.
Incremental scope & isolated validation: Deliver each section in isolation. If possible, include a minimal test or example so I can validate one block at a time before merging.
Consistent formatting: Format all code (e.g., with Prettier) to ensure consistent indentation and braces. Do not alter comment markers.
Versioned backups: Whenever replacing a block, keep the previous version in a comment or separate file. This ensures easy rollback if something breaks.

title: Character Portrait
description: Transform reference photos into high-quality portraits

variations.name: Visual Anchor Method
variations.description: Three-step process: analyze facial structure, summarize key features, then merge with style reference. Best when you have both likeness and style images.
variations.template:
Step 1:
Analyze the attached reference photographs to identify the subject's visual anchor: the fixed facial characteristics that must remain unchanged to preserve likeness. These include, at minimum, overall craniofacial structure, eye spacing and orientation, nasal form, mouth proportions, jawline, and any distinctive asymmetries or contours.

Once this visual anchor is established, reinterpret the subject through the conventions of classical portraiture. Describe the figure in the style of a 19th-century academic oil painting, introducing restrained idealization—refinement of skin, lighting, and expression—while preserving immediate recognizability. The final portrait should convey gravity, dignity, and psychological depth, balancing faithful likeness with the pathos and nobility characteristic of high academic painting.

Step 2: Provide a summary of this Visual Anchor Then ask for a Style Reference Image in order to move to image generation.

Step 3: I will provide a Style Reference Image. You must generate a high-fidelity image that merges the subject's "Visual Anchor" with the style, medium, and atmosphere of the reference image. The subject must look like they belong in that world, as if they were the original sitter for that specific piece of art.

Let's Begin: I am uploading the likeness references now.

variations.name: Likeness Lock Method
variations.description: Creates explicit constraint checklist before generation to prioritize identity preservation. Best when likeness accuracy is critical.
variations.template:
Step 1 — Likeness Lock + Visual Anchor extraction
"Analyze the attached likeness reference photos. Your primary objective is preserving identity.
Priority order: facial geometry and feature placement (highest) > expression > pose > lighting > wardrobe > background/painterly effects (lowest).
Define the subject's Visual Anchor as a set of non-negotiable constraints. Lock these elements: head/craniofacial silhouette, relative feature placement, eye spacing and tilt, eyelid shape, brow shape and distance to eyes, nose bridge/tip/nostril geometry, philtrum length, mouth width and lip shape, chin projection, jaw angle/width, and any distinctive asymmetries or markers.
Allowed changes: painterly rendering, skin finish, lighting design, color palette, edge softness, canvas/varnish effects.
Disallowed changes: altering facial proportions, moving features, beautifying asymmetries, changing age/ethnicity cues."

Step 2 — Output constraints, then request style reference
"Output the Visual Anchor as a bullet checklist of explicit constraints (10–20 items) written as 'must match' statements. Then provide a short compliance plan describing how you will keep the anchor intact during style transfer.
Then ask me for a Style Reference Image to proceed."

Step 3 — Generate
"Using the Style Reference Image, generate a 19th-century academic oil portrait that matches its brushwork, palette, lighting (chiaroscuro), composition conventions, and surface finish. The subject must remain immediately recognizable from the likeness references by strictly adhering to the Visual Anchor checklist.
Before finalizing, perform a quick internal cross-check: confirm each anchor item is satisfied."
Let's Begin: I am uploading the likeness references now.

variations.name: Character Reference Only (No Style Image)
variations.description: Generates classical oil portrait directly from reference photos without style image. Best for standalone portraits with automatic style.
variations.template:
Analyze the uploaded reference images to identify and preserve the subject's Visual Anchor: the immutable facial characteristics that define their identity. This includes exact craniofacial structure, head shape, forehead height, cheekbone placement, jawline geometry, eye spacing and orientation, eyelid shape, nasal bridge and tip, mouth width and lip proportions, ear placement, and any distinctive asymmetries or contours. These features must remain anatomically unchanged to ensure immediate and unmistakable likeness.

Render the subject as a classical, museum-quality oil portrait in the tradition of refined academic painting.

Apply idealization only at the surface level—subtle refinement of skin texture, unified tonal transitions, and painterly handling of edges—while strictly preserving the subject's facial proportions, expression, and bone structure as seen in the reference images. Avoid transformation toward an archetypal face.

Clothing should be simple and classical in form, rendered in soft natural fabrics with minimal ornamentation, allowing focus to remain on the face. Brushwork should be smooth and intentional, conveying the materiality of oil paint without obscuring defining features.

The final image should read as a refined classical oil painting that depicts the same individual from the reference images, instantly recognizable, with identity fully preserved and expressed through a restrained, timeless painterly aesthetic.

title: Academic Drawing
description: Convert an image or create an academic drawing of an idealized male figure in classical style

variations.name: Convert Uploaded Image
variations.description: Transforms your uploaded image into an academic figure study drawing while preserving the original pose and character.
variations.template:
Convert the uploaded image into an academic drawing of a nude male figure presented in a balanced, idealized standing pose derived from classical statuary and 19th-century academic practice, emphasizing idealized male beauty. Preserve the general pose and character of the original subject while refining it to classical ideals.

The figure stands upright with weight evenly distributed, one leg bearing slightly more load while the opposite leg relaxes, creating a subtle, restrained contrapposto.

The pelvis is level and stable; the torso is erect and open, with the rib cage lifted and aligned cleanly over the hips. The shoulders are relaxed and square, allowing the chest to read broadly and clearly.

The arms are held in a natural, neutral arrangement—one arm resting loosely at the side, the other gently bent at the elbow with the hand relaxed near the hip—posed to reveal proportional relationships without gesture or narrative intent.

The head is upright and centered, facing forward with a slight classical turn. Facial features are idealized in the Roman tradition: strong brow, straight forehead, pronounced aquiline nose, and a calm, impassive expression.

Hair is short, close-cropped, and classical in character—neatly contoured to the skull, with minimal volume, subtle wave or texture at the crown, and no modern styling or exaggerated curls.

The pose emphasizes symmetry, proportion, and clarity of form, allowing the ideal male anatomy to be read in full: harmonious relationships between head, torso, and limbs; clear transitions between major masses; balanced distribution of weight.

Rendered in the tradition of 19th-century French academic draftsmanship (Bargue, Gérôme, early École des Beaux-Arts). Emphasize structural clarity, anatomical rigor, and restraint.

Use charcoal or graphite with precise contour control, subtle variation in line weight, and economical modeling. Shading should rely on clear planes, measured tonal transitions, and unified halftones rather than expressive or sketch-like marks.

Anatomy must be deliberate and canonical: clear articulation of rib cage, pelvis, scapulae, and major muscle groups, with emphasis on volume and proportion over surface texture.

Lighting is controlled and directional, atelier-style, using a single dominant light source to establish calm shadow masses and restrained highlights.

The background remains minimal or blank, reinforcing the studio study context.

Overall effect: a museum-quality academic figure study—idealized, disciplined, and timeless—classical in spirit, restrained in execution, and visually clean.

title: Artist Guide
description: Expert guidance for reproducing reference images in oil painting, watercolor, or drawing with technical analysis

variations.name: Oil Painting Guide
variations.description: Step-by-step guidance for reproducing images in oil paint. Includes palette recommendations, layering techniques, and visual reference generation.
variations.template:
Role: You are a Master Oil Painter and Art Instructor. Your goal is to help me reproduce the attached reference image as a high-quality oil painting.

Task 1: Stylistic Diagnosis
Analyze the attached image. Identify its specific technical style (e.g., Classical Glazing, Alla Prima, Impasto, or Tonalism). Explain how this style dictates the painting process (e.g., "This piece requires a wet-on-wet approach to preserve the soft gradients").

Task 2: Technical Breakdown
Based on your diagnosis, provide:

The Color Palette: List the specific pigments required. Suggest a "Limited Palette" version if appropriate for color harmony.

Step-by-Step Guide: Determine the optimal number of steps for this specific style. Organize them logically, such as:

The Foundation: (e.g., Imprimatura vs. detailed charcoal transfer).

The Underlayer: (e.g., Grisaille, Verdaccio, or a rough "Ebauche").

Development: (e.g., Building opaque mid-tones or layering transparent glazes).

Finishing touches: (e.g., Final highlights, scumbling, or varnish-ready details).

Task 3: Interactive Guidance
Provide high-level instructions for these steps now. End your response by reminding me that I can ask for:

"Detailed Instructions for Step X" (for specific brushwork and mixing ratios).

"Generate a visual reference for Step X" (to see a generated example of what my canvas should look like midway through that specific stage).

variations.name: Watercolor Guide
variations.description: Instructions for watercolor techniques including wet-on-wet, masking, and transparency control. Covers paper selection and pigment properties.
variations.template:
Role: You are a Master Watercolorist and Art Instructor. Your goal is to help me reproduce the attached reference image using professional watercolor techniques.

Task 1: Stylistic & Technical Diagnosis
Analyze the attached image. Identify the watercolor approach best suited for this piece (e.g., Loose & Expressive, Botanical Realism, or Wet-on-Wet Impressionism).

Light Preservation: Identify the "pure whites" in the image and advise if I should use masking fluid or paint around them (negative painting).

Paper Choice: Suggest the ideal paper texture (Hot Press for detail, Cold Press for general use, or Rough for texture).

Task 2: Technical Breakdown

The Palette & Transparency: List the necessary pigments. Specify which should be Transparent, Semi-Opaque, or Granulating to match the textures in the reference.

Step-by-Step Guide: Break the process into logical watercolor phases:

Phase 1: The Sketch & Masking: (Guidelines for a light graphite sketch and preserving highlights).

Phase 2: The Initial Washes (Tea Consistency): (Establishing the lightest values and "under-glow" using wet-on-wet or flat washes).

Phase 3: Building Form (Milk Consistency): (Developing mid-tones, defining shapes, and managing edges—soft vs. hard).

Phase 4: Values & Shadows (Honey Consistency): (Adding the darkest "darks," dry-brush textures, and fine details).

Task 3: Interactive Guidance
Provide high-level instructions for these steps now. End your response by reminding me that I can ask for:

"Detailed Instructions for Step X" (including specific water-to-paint ratios and brush types).

"Generate a visual reference for Step X" (to see a generated example of the painting in its "ugly duckling" mid-wash stage).

variations.name: Drawing Guide
variations.description: Comprehensive drawing guidance covering graphite, charcoal, and carbon techniques. Includes value mapping and texture rendering methods.
variations.template:
Role: You are a Master Draftsman and Drawing Instructor. Your goal is to help me reproduce the attached reference image as a high-quality pencil drawing.

Task 1: Stylistic & Technical Diagnosis
Analyze the attached image. Identify the drawing approach best suited for this piece (e.g., Photorealism, Expressive Sketching, Classical Academic Study, or High-Contrast Tonalism).

Material Recommendations: Suggest the best medium for the job (e.g., Standard Graphite, Charcoal for deep blacks, or Carbon pencil for matte finishes) and necessary tools (kneaded erasers, blending stumps, or specific paper "tooth").

Texture Strategy: Briefly explain the primary technique needed for the dominant textures in the image (e.g., "Use tight circulisim for the skin pores," or "Use aggressive cross-hatching for the fabric folds").

Task 2: Technical Breakdown
Based on your diagnosis, provide:

The "Palette" (Grade Selection): List the specific range of pencils required (e.g., "You will need a hard HB for layout, a versatile 2B for mid-tones, and a soft 8B for darkest shadows").

Step-by-Step Guide: Divide the process into logical drawing phases that build value gradually:

Phase 1: The Framework (Hard Pencils): (Guidelines for accurate proportions, gesture, and light "envelope" shapes).

Phase 2: Mapping Shadows (Mid-Range Pencils): (Establishing the "bedbug line" separating light and shadow families; flat tonal mapping).

Phase 3: Modeling Form & Blending: (Developing gradients, turning soft edges, and deciding whether to blend with tools or rely on distinct hatch marks).

Phase 4: Deepening Darks & Texture: (Pushing contrast to the limit with softest pencils and rendering specific surface details).

Phase 5: Subtractive Highlights: (Using erasers to "draw" back into the tones to create crisp highlights or stray hairs).

Task 3: Interactive Guidance
Provide high-level instructions for these steps now. End your response by reminding me that I can ask for:

"Detailed Instructions for Step X" (including specific pencil grades, pressure guidance, and stroke types).

"Generate a visual reference for Step X" (to see a generated example of what the drawing should look like at that specific stage of completion, e.g., just the line work).

variations.template:
Convert this photograph while preserving the original characters, setting, composition, and narrative context exactly as captured. Reinterpret the image with fine-art, editorial quality inspired by Tina Barney's photographic style.

Apply the visual language of large-format, museum-grade color photography: naturalistic yet deliberate color, soft but controlled contrast, and a restrained, painterly palette. Skin tones should appear realistic and dimensional, with subtle warmth and tonal depth. Whites should be creamy rather than stark; shadows should retain detail without appearing flat or crushed.

Maintain a sense of quiet psychological presence and observational intimacy. The image should feel composed, intentional, and slightly detached—neither cinematic nor stylized for drama. Avoid exaggerated sharpness, HDR effects, or artificial lighting artifacts.

Upgrade the technical quality to resemble a contemporary high-end digital or medium-format camera: refined dynamic range, clean micro-detail, smooth tonal transitions, and film-like color depth without visible grain. Preserve natural imperfections and avoid cosmetic retouching that would flatten character or environment.

The final result should read as gallery-ready fine art photography—editorial in rigor, restrained in execution, and suitable for museum or print publication.

The aesthetic should feel gloomy and feature the unique optical qualities of antique lenses, including a very shallow depth of field with sharp selective focus on the main subject, rapidly falling off into a painterly, swirling bokeh and soft atmospheric blur. The lighting is high-contrast but refined for a fine art print, with rich, deep blacks retaining subtle detail, and luminous, glowing whites. Instead of heavy damage, incorporate subtle, organic imperfections inherent to the hand-made process: delicate chemical swirls, faint emulsion irregularities near the edges, and soft, natural vignetting. The final texture should feel tactile, timeless, and haunting, possessing the quality of a masterfully crafted, hand-printed photograph suitable for framing.

title: Component Adaptation (Design System)
description: Adapt components with automated color extraction, state testing, and pixel-perfect verification (ΔE < 2.0, ≥99.9% match)
template:
Component: {{component_name}}

I need to adapt this component to my m3-design-v2 design system with PERFECT visual fidelity. I will provide a screenshot and original code. Follow the enhanced systematic workflow with automated color extraction, state testing, and pixel-perfect verification. CRITICAL: Perfect visual fidelity is non-negotiable - no close enough approximations allowed.

Phase 1 Color Extraction and Analysis. First extract ALL colors from the reference screenshot using an automated Playwright script. The script should navigate to the reference, query all elements, and extract computed color values for every text element, background, border, and interactive state. Create a comprehensive color mapping table showing reference color in RGB, hex value, closest design system token, whether it's an exact match, and what action is required. If a design system semantic token like var(--md-sys-color-on-surface) does NOT match the reference color exactly check the delta E, if delta E is 2.0 or higher you MUST create component-specific color tokens. Never approximate or use close enough colors. For example if the reference uses Tailwind stone-900 rgb(28,25,23) but design system on-surface is rgb(18,23,20), the delta E is high, so create --wy-component-title-color with the exact reference value. Document why semantic tokens don't work for this specific design. This prevents the critical error of using wrong semantic tokens that cause subtle visual hierarchy mismatches.

Phase 1 continued Analysis and Planning. Analyze the screenshot for layout structure, typography hierarchy, interactive elements, spacing patterns, and visual details like border radius shadows and transitions. Review the original code for hardcoded values to replace. Look for color hex codes, pixel spacing, font sizes and families, border radius values, and transition durations. Create a complete token mapping table. Identify missing design system assets.

Phase 2 Design System Updates. If analysis reveals colors that don't match existing tokens exactly, add new component-specific color tokens to m3-design-v2/src/styles/tokens.css. Follow naming pattern --wy-component-name-property-color. Always include dark mode variants in @media prefers-color-scheme dark block. Add spacing shape or motion tokens if required. Document rationale for each new token explaining why semantic tokens don't provide exact match. Use existing patterns, semantic names, provide dark mode variants, and document rationale in comments.

Phase 3 Implementation. Create Web Component in m3-design-v2/src/components/wy-[name].js using LitElement. Define reactive properties. Import fonts in Shadow DOM for Playfair Display and Material Symbols Outlined. Use design system tokens exclusively with absolutely zero hardcoded values. Define component-specific color tokens in :host block with fallback values like --wy-component-title-color: #1C1917. Use these specific tokens in styles not generic semantic tokens. Follow Material Design 3 state layer patterns using ::before pseudo-elements with opacity transitions. Add focus-visible outlines 3px solid with 2px offset. Never use !important. Use semantic HTML. Component structure: import from lit, extend LitElement, declare static properties, define static styles with all design system tokens, define component-specific color tokens in :host, implement state layers for interactive elements, implement render method.

Phase 4 Build and Prepare Testing. Build design system with npm run build, start dev server with npm run dev, create test page if needed importing tokens and component.

Phase 5.1 Color Accuracy Testing MANDATORY. Create and run test-color-accuracy.py script. Extract reference colors from original using Playwright script that loads reference and extracts computed getComputedStyle values for all text backgrounds and borders converting to RGB tuples. Define REFERENCE_COLORS dictionary with element name to RGB tuple mapping like title: (28, 25, 23) for stone-900. Extract implementation colors using same method from component shadow root. Calculate color delta using Euclidean distance formula. For each color verify delta E is less than 2.0 which means imperceptible difference. Delta E between 2.0 and 5.0 is noticeable, above 5.0 is clearly visible. Print formatted table showing element, actual RGB, expected RGB, and delta value. Success criteria: ALL colors must have delta E less than 2.0. If test fails identify which colors have high delta, verify component uses correct component-specific tokens not generic semantic tokens, ensure tokens defined in :host block for Shadow DOM, re-run extraction to verify reference colors, update token values. Common failures: using var(--md-sys-color-on-surface) when reference uses Tailwind stone palette, tokens not cascading into Shadow DOM, circular variable references like --spacing-sm: var(--spacing-sm, ...), CDN cache serving old bundle.

Phase 5.2 Interactive State Testing MANDATORY. Extract state colors from reference for hover focus active and disabled states using Playwright to hover elements, press Tab for focus, click for active. For each interactive element verify default rest state colors match reference exactly with delta E less than 2.0, hover state border background color changes match, focus state keyboard indicator matches with outline style color width and offset, active pressed state click appearance matches, disabled state opacity cursor and colors match if applicable, loading state indicators match if applicable, error state styling matches if applicable, and state transitions animation duration and easing match reference. Test all interactive states for buttons chips links form inputs. Success criteria: all state colors match reference with delta E less than 2.0, state transitions occur, no states missing, focus indicators meet WCAG. Common issues: using :hover without state layer pseudo-element, missing :focus-visible styles, hardcoding state colors instead of state layer opacity, missing disabled state, transitions too fast or slow.

Phase 5.3 Pixel Perfect Visual Comparison MANDATORY. Use Playwright plus PIL to capture screenshots from reference and implementation at exact same viewport like 1200x900. Convert images to RGB numpy arrays. Calculate per-pixel difference using absolute value of array subtraction. Create diff heatmap where pixels within tolerance of 2 RGB points per channel are green and pixels outside tolerance are red. Calculate match percentage as matching pixels divided by total pixels times 100. Generate visual outputs: diff heatmap PNG with green for matching red for different, side-by-side comparison PNG with reference on left implementation on right with labels. Success criteria: match percentage must be 99.9% or higher allowing only 0.1% for anti-aliasing differences, no visible differences in side-by-side, diff heatmap shows only minor anti-aliasing if any. Acceptable differences: font rendering 1-2px due to browser OS, anti-aliasing on rounded corners within tolerance, sub-pixel rendering under 2 points per channel. Unacceptable: wrong colors different hue saturation lightness, wrong spacing margin padding gap offsets, wrong font sizes or weights, wrong border radius or shapes, missing elements or incorrect positioning. If match under 99.9%: review heatmap to identify problem areas, check if acceptable anti-aliasing or real issues, increase tolerance slightly if only anti-aliasing max 5, if real differences fix implementation and retest, never lower success threshold.

Phase 5.4 Functional Testing. Verify all original functionality preserved, test modal open close, click handlers, navigation, keyboard shortcuts, event dispatching, state management. Run automated functional test or manual verification.

Phase 5.5 Design System Compliance. Scan component code for hardcoded hex codes, magic number spacing, arbitrary durations, !important declarations. Verify 100% token usage. Zero hardcoded values allowed.

Phase 6 Deliverables. Provide: 1 Color extraction report table showing reference RGB, hex value, design system token, whether exact match, and action taken. 2 Token mapping report complete table original value to token with status. 3 Color accuracy test results showing all delta E values under 2.0 with formatted table and max delta reported. 4 Interactive state test results showing all states verified with hover focus active disabled tested and screenshot evidence. 5 Pixel perfect comparison results with match percentage 99.9% or higher, diff heatmap image path, side-by-side comparison image path, and acceptable vs unacceptable differences documented. 6 Complete component code with full Web Component implementation, registration in src/main.js, component.json entry with props and examples, usage example in markup. 7 Design system updates if any showing new tokens added to tokens.css, dark mode variants, and rationale for why semantic tokens didn't work. 8 Integration instructions for using component, available API, event listeners, build and deploy commands.

Success criteria ALL must pass: Color accuracy with all elements delta E under 2.0 imperceptible difference, pixel match with 99.9% or higher match percentage, all interactive states tested and verified matching reference, visual fidelity where component matches screenshot exactly, token usage 100% design tokens zero hardcoded values, Playwright tests all passing, dark mode works in both schemes, no console errors, semantic HTML, ARIA labels present, focus states visible and accessible.

Anti-patterns to avoid: hardcoded colors hex rgb rgba, magic number spacing, arbitrary transitions, !important declarations, changing background-color on hover directly, hardcoded border-radius, skipping dark mode testing, forgetting Shadow DOM fonts, inline styles for theming, delivering without verification, using generic semantic tokens when reference needs specific colors, assuming semantic token names match without verifying RGB values, testing functionality before colors are correct, approximating colors instead of exact match.

Design system compliance for colors: use var(--md-sys-color-*) or var(--wy-*), provide dark mode variants, use color-mix() for transparency. Typography: use var(--font-serif) var(--font-sans) var(--font-display), clamp() for fluid scaling, design system letter spacing. Spacing: use var(--spacing-*) xxs through 3xl, follow 8px grid, clamp() for responsive. Shape: use var(--md-sys-shape-corner-*), corner-full for capsules. Motion: use var(--md-sys-motion-duration-*) and var(--md-sys-motion-easing-*), no magic durations. Interactive states: hover with ::before overlay, opacity var(--md-sys-state-hover-opacity), focus 3px outline 2px offset, never change background directly.

Execute complete workflow with all testing phases 5.1 through 5.5 and provide all 8 deliverables with color extraction report, color accuracy delta E results, state testing results, pixel perfect comparison with heatmap and match percentage, complete code, design system updates, and integration instructions.

title: Audio Essay Topic Discovery
description: Four-step research workflow to discover interdisciplinary topics and generate audio essay scripts

steps.name: Conceptual Decomposition
steps.instructions: Start by entering your topic. This step will identify three distinct conceptual pillars that define your topic.
steps.template:
Topic: {{topic}}

Role: You are a Technical Systems Analyst, Historical Researcher, and culturally sophisticated guide. Your objective is to extract high-density, interdisciplinary data from a provided starting point.

CORE THEMATIC SCOPE

All output must be inspired by these specific domains. If a topic does not intersect with at least one of these, it is rejected:

Material Science/Craft
Classical revival architecture (e.g., Greek Revival)
Structural Engineering
Neoclassical Art
Southern Gothic Realism and Writers
18th/19th-century Economic History
American history
Biographies of gay writers, artists, and historical figures
Alcohol, wine, and beer
The American South
New England, Boston, Salem, and Marblehead
Antiques collecting (primarily American, English, and French)

MECHANISMS & INSTITUTIONS (OPTIONAL LENSES)

Use these when they strengthen the synthesis or provide a causal throughline:

Interpersonal relationship (patronage, kinship, mentorship, rivalry, marriage, inheritance networks)
Credit, banking, and merchant finance
Insurance and risk pricing (marine, fire, life)
Law, contracts, and property regimes (admiralty, probate, incorporation)
Logistics and port governance (customs, warehousing, quarantine, lighthouses)
Printing, publishing, and information networks (newspapers, circulars, ledgers)

PHASE 1: CONCEPTUAL DECOMPOSITION

Upon receiving a Level 0 topic, identify three distinct conceptual pillars (technical, historical, or structural) that define the topic.

Format: List the three pillars as noun-heavy phrases. No descriptions.

MANDATORY LINGUISTIC CONSTRAINTS (Zero-Tolerance for Fluff)

No "Throat-Clearing": Delete phrases like "It is worth noting," "Let's dive into," or "As an expert curator".
No Decorative Adjectives: Avoid words like stately, haunting, evocative, rich, or vibrant.
No Litotes: Avoid indirect assertions (e.g., "not unlike," "not insignificant"). Use direct, assertive language.
No Personification: History does not "whisper" or "tell stories." It "codifies," "catalyzes," or "results in."
No Narrative Transitions: Do not provide summaries or "Curator's Notes". Provide data immediately.

PHASE 2: THE CURRICULUM MENU

Generate 10 Level 1 topics.

Target Ratio: 30% direct correlation / 70% tangential/interdisciplinary connections.

Technical Justification: One sentence (max 15 words) per item. State the precise overlap with the Core Thematic Scope. Mechanisms & Institutions may be used when useful.

Requirement: No adjectives. No introductory text.

Format each as:

[Number]. [Topic Title]: [One sentence technical justification]

Example:
1. Maritime Insurance Pricing Models in Early Boston: Quantifies risk assessment mechanisms for trans-Atlantic shipping routes.
2. Probate Records and Furniture Attribution: Links documented estate inventories to surviving Federal-period cabinetwork.

PHASE 3: TECHNICAL ABSTRACTS

Suggest two Technical Abstracts (Level 2) for the selected topic.

For each abstract:

Sentence 1: Quantify scope (Dates, geography, or technical specifications).
Sentence 2: Identify the primary mechanical, structural, or literary evolution.
Sentence 3: State the measurable historical or material outcome.

Format:

### Abstract A: [Title]
[Three sentences as specified above]

### Abstract B: [Title]
[Three sentences as specified above]

- No Decorative Adjectives
- No Litotes

steps.name: Audio Essay Generation
steps.instructions: Select one of the abstracts from Step 3. This generates the final audio essay script prompt for use in a new chat.
steps.template:
Selected Abstract: {{selected_abstract}}

---AUDIO ESSAY SCRIPT PROMPT---

Copy the text below and use it in a NEW chat window to generate your audio essay:

---BEGIN PROMPT---
Topic: {{selected_abstract}}

Write a twenty-five-hundred-word essay on the topic above. Structure the essay entirely in paragraphs, avoiding lists, bullet points, or outline formatting. The goal is to create a continuous narrative suitable for listening as if it were a chapter of a book read aloud by a professional narrator.

Style and Language Rules:

Spell out numbers and dates fully. For example:
Instead of "first," write "first."
Instead of "nineteen fifties," write "nineteen fifties."
Instead of "twenty twenty-four," write "twenty twenty-four."
Instead of "five percent," write "five percent."
Instead of "twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week," write "twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week."
Avoid abbreviations and acronyms unless they are spelled out in full (e.g., write "McKinsey and Company" instead of "McKinsey and Co.").
Do not use symbols (percent, dollar, ampersand). Always write the words out.
Avoid inline references such as "(Smith, nineteen ninety-nine)" or "[one]". Instead, all references and sources should be collected at the end of the essay in a concise "References" section.
Write in complete sentences, maintaining fluid transitions between ideas.
Favor descriptive language that aids the ear. Repetition for clarity is acceptable if it improves oral comprehension.

Linguistic Constraints (Zero-Tolerance for Fluff):

No "Throat-Clearing": Delete phrases like "It is worth noting," "Let us dive into," or "As an expert curator."
No Decorative Adjectives: Avoid words like stately, haunting, evocative, rich, or vibrant.
No Litotes: Avoid indirect assertions (e.g., "not unlike," "not insignificant"). Use direct, assertive language.
No Personification: History does not "whisper" or "tell stories." It "codifies," "catalyzes," or "results in."
No Narrative Transitions: Do not provide summaries or "Curator's Notes." Provide data immediately.

Audience and Depth:

Write for a highly intelligent general audience that expects both accuracy and originality. Provide insights that go beyond common knowledge and surface-level facts.
Incorporate historical, cultural, and technical context where relevant to deepen understanding.
Use metaphors or analogies sparingly and only if they improve clarity.

Factual Rigor:

Verify claims with precise supporting details.
Where possible, provide exact figures, dates, names, or dimensions to anchor the narrative in concrete fact.
Do not leave generalizations unsupported.
Ensure balance: acknowledge counterpoints or differing interpretations when relevant, and explain why one perspective became dominant.

Tone:

Aim for the cadence of a long-form essay or nonfiction book chapter. Think of the style of Bill Bryson or Alan Taylor: approachable, informed, and precise.
Strive for clarity without oversimplifying.
Keep the prose natural for the ear; avoid overly dense academic phrasing.

Conclusion and Learning Extensions:

At the end of the essay, provide a short "References" section with the sources used.
After the references, concisely state three areas for deeper learning. These should not be remedial but rather fascinating and informative avenues for a curious and well-studied reader to pursue further.
---END PROMPT---

title: Portrait Iconography Brainstorm
description: Brainstorm visual symbolism for portraits using 19th-century art history and iconographic language
template:
Core message/intent of the artwork: {{message}}

Act as a specialist in 19th-century Art History and Iconography. I want to brainstorm a portrait of a subject that visually communicates a specific hidden message.

Provide a detailed breakdown of how an artist of this era would communicate the message entered above using the following four categories:

* The 'Language of Objects': Suggest 3-4 specific items (memento mori, flora, or household objects) that act as metaphors for the message.
* Composition & Lighting: Describe how the use of shadows (chiaroscuro), perspective, or the placement of the subject in the frame reinforces the secret meaning.
* The 'Somatic' (Body) Code: Detail specific gestures, gazes, or anatomical focuses (e.g., tension in the hands, the direction of the eyes) that hint at the internal state.
* Environmental Cues: Describe a background, window view, or architectural detail that provides a 'thematic echoes' of the main message.

Ensure the suggestions feel grounded in the 19th-century aesthetic (Romanticism, Realism, or the Gilded Age) rather than modern fantasy.

variables.name: message
variables.label: Core Message/Intent
variables.placeholder: e.g., Hidden grief, secret ambition, forbidden love, moral conflict
